questiontext.text:
Applications of trigonometry to triangles


Area of a triangle

The area \(S\) of any triangle is given by \(S=\dfrac{1}{2}\times (\text{base}) \times (\text{perpendicular} \, \text{height})\) where 'perpendicular height' means the perpendicular distance from the side called the 'base' to the opposite vertex. Thus for the right-angled triangle shown bellow \(\quad S=\dfrac{1}{2} \ b\ a.\) For the obtuse-angled triangle (b) the area is \(S=\dfrac{1}{2}\ b \ h.\)

If we use \(C\) to denote the angle \(ACB\) in Figure (b) then

\(\qquad \sin (180-C) = \dfrac{h}{a} \qquad\) (triangle \(BCD\) is right-angled)

Therefore,

\( \qquad h=a \sin (180-C) = a\sin C \quad\) (see the graph of the sine wave or expand \(\sin (180-c)\))

\(\qquad \boxed{S=\dfrac{1}{2}\,b\,a \sin C} \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad\) 1(a)

By other similar constructions we could demonstrate that

\(\qquad \boxed{S=\dfrac{1}{2}\, a\, c\, \sin B } \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad\) 1(b)

and

\(\qquad \boxed{S=\dfrac{1}{2}\, b\, c\, \sin A} \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad\) 1(c)

Note the pattern here: in each formula for the area the angle involved is the one between the sides whose lengths occur in that expression.

Clearly if \(C\) is a right-angle (so \(\sin C=1\)) then

\(\qquad S=\dfrac{1}{2}\, b\, a \quad\) as for Figure (a).

Note: from now on we will not generally write ‘\(\equiv\)’ but use the more usual ‘\(=\)’.


The Sine rule

The Sine rule is a formula which, if we are given certain information about a triangle, enables us to fully 'solve the triangle' i.e. obtain the lengths of all three sides and the value of all three angles.

To show the rule we note that from the formulae (1a) and (1b) for the area \(S\) of the triangle \(ABC\) in Figure 33 we have

\(\qquad ba\sin C=a c\sin B \quad\) or \(\quad \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C}\)

Similarly using (1b) and (1c)

\(\qquad a c\sin B = bc\sin A \quad\) or \(\quad \dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B}\)

Key Point

The Sine Rule

For any triangle \(ABC\) where \(a\) is the length of the side opposite angle \(A\), \(b\) the side length opposite angle \(B\) and \(c\) the side length opposite angle \(C\) states

\[\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C}\]


Use of the Sine rule

To be able to fully determine all the angles and sides of a triangle it follows from the Sine rule that we must know

\(\qquad\) either \(\quad\) two angles and one side: (knowing two angles of a triangle really means that all three are known since the sum of the angles is \(180^\circ\)

\(\qquad\) or \(\quad\) two sides and an angle opposite one of those two sides.


Example

Solve the triangle \(ABC\) given that \(a=32\, \text{cm},\, \, b=46\, \text{cm}\, \) and angle \( B=63.25^\circ.\)

Solution

Using the first pair of equations in the Sine rule (previous Key Point) we have

\[ \dfrac{32}{\sin A} = \dfrac{46}{\sin 63.25^\circ}\qquad \therefore\qquad \sin A=\dfrac{32}{46}\sin 63.25^\circ=0.6212\]

so

\[ A= \sin^{-1}(0.6212)=38.4^\circ \quad (\text{by} \, \text{calculator})\]

You should, however, note carefully that because of the form of the graph of the sine function there are two angles between \(0^\circ\) and \(180^\circ\) which have the same value for their sine i.e. \(x\) and \((180-x).\) See figure bellow.

In our example

\( \qquad A=\sin^{-1}(0.6212) = 38.4^\circ\)

or

\(\qquad A=180^\circ-38.4^\circ = 141.6^\circ.\)

However since we are given that angle \(B\) is \(63.25^\circ\), the value of \(141.6^\circ\) for angle \(A\) is clearly impossible.

To complete the problem we simply note that

\( \qquad C=180^\circ-(38.4^\circ+63.25^\circ) = 78.35^\circ \)

The remaining side \(c\) is calculated from the Sine rule, using either \(a\) and \(\sin A\) or \(b\) and \(\sin B.\)
